channel.title: BBC News - Latin America & Caribbean
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Mexico metro collapse: 'All I ever wanted was for my son to come home'
item.description: The mother of the youngest victim of Mexico's metro crash takes on some of the country's richest people.

item.title: Brazil legend Pele says he is 'recovering very well' after surgery
item.description: Brazil legend Pele says he is "recovering well" from a recent operation after briefly being readmitted to intensive care.

item.title: Migrants in Texas: US 'to fly thousands back to Haiti'
item.description: Thousands of migrants are camping under a Texas-Mexico border bridge, in squalid conditions.

item.title: Venezuela judiciary aiding repression, UN finds
item.description: A fact-finding mission says the justice system allowed serious human rights violations to happen.

item.title: Haiti PM sacks justice minister amid murder inquiry
item.description: The move comes after charges were sought against the prime minister over the president's killing.

item.title: Bitcoin protests in El Salvador against cryptocurrency as legal tender
item.description: The demonstrators burn Bitcoin machines, a week after the cryptocurrency became legal tender.

item.title: Nicki Minaj: Trinidad minister criticises rapper's vaccine tweet
item.description: The singer has been accused of spreading vaccine disinformation on the social media site.

item.title: Mexico drug lord 'The Viceroy' sentenced to 28 years
item.description: Vicente Carrillo Fuentes took control of the Juárez cartel after his brother died in a botched operation.

item.title: Mexico rescues foreign guests abducted from hotel
item.description: Some 22 foreigners and 16 Mexicans are rescued after gunmen kidnapped them in San Luis Potosi state.

item.title: Abimael Guzmán: The rebel leader who sowed terror
item.description: Guzmán led the Maoist rebel group which in the 1980s almost brought the Peruvian state to its knees.

item.title: 'I'll be at front of queue to change my slave name'
item.description: Descendants of African slaves welcome a Dutch city's decision to scrap fees for changing names.

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The Paralympic dream that started at the supermarket
item.description: Aruba had never had a Paralympic team until a student in her 20s decided to make it happen.

item.title: Wildlife photo: Is this the world's most beautiful mosquito?
item.description: Both beauty and beast. A Sabethes mosquito is visually stunning but it's also a carrier of disease.

item.title: Image of bird at US-Mexico border wall wins contest
item.description: The winning image by Mexican photographer Alejandro Prieto shows a roadrunner at the border wall.

item.title: Mexico earthquake: Lights seen in sky during tremor near Acapulco
item.description: The magnitude-seven quake struck the country's Pacific coast, near the resort of Acapulco.

item.title: Mexico: Flash flooding sweeps away cars after heavy rain
item.description: Heavy rain in central Mexico sparked flash floods in Ecatepec and Nexahualcóyotl.

item.title: ICYMI: Catwalk hail storm and cheeky capybaras
item.description: Some of the stories that you may have missed this week.

item.title: Paddle boarder's close encounter with two curious whales
item.description: A drone filmed what the paddle boarder, out on the water on her birthday, calls a "magical moment".

item.title: Daniel Dias: History's greatest para-swimmer
item.description: Daniel Dias has won more than 25 medals for Brazil over the past four Paralympic Games but will be retiring after Tokyo.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Mother mourns daughter killed during christening
item.description: Locals say 22 people died when a church collapsed during a mass christening.
